results.title: Small world = Le Monde est petit
results.creator_credit: Jacques Valentin, National Film Board of Canada and Unesco
results.brief_description: Children from some forty countries were asked to give their interpretation in drawings of the world from pre-history to the year 3000 AD. This film, made within the framework of UNESCO’s project for the mutual understanding of Orient and Occident, shows that the imagination of children knows no frontiers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacques Valentin, National Film Board of Canada and Unesco

results.title: Small smoke at Blaze Creek
results.creator_credit: Michael Scott, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Forest fire in mountainous British Columbia, as experienced by the men who must try to quench it from the air and at close quarters on the ground. Over half of fire outbreaks occur through carelessness, and this film affords a close, vivid view of the result: a whole mountainside turned into a searing, crackling holocaust until nothing remains but grey, desolate waste—mute reproach to all who travel or work in the forests. (Awards: Berlin; Belgrade.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Scott, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Small island, big fight
results.creator_credit: Aven S Noah, Rosemary Hesp, Trevor Graham, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Australia and Junjidys Productions
results.brief_description: …Where I come from is Murray Island. We call it Mer. The home of the famous Mabo land rights case. We won that battle, but now we’ve got a new fight on our hands…this time with outside fishing fleets over who can profit from our waters. (Aven S. Noah) Situated on the eastern side of the Torres Strait between Papua New Guinea and Australia, Murray Island or Mer, is home to around 450 indigenous people with each family belonging to one of eight clans. Following the historic Mabo case which won recognition for traditional ownership of their land, the Mer people are now fighting for the same recognition of their sea - land and sea are all part of Aboriginal territory and have a historical cultural link to their spiritual beliefs and customs. Their sea is being invaded by commercial fishing fleets and local islanders are struggling to compete - already some have left the Island and three-quarters of the population are on welfare. What has not been resolved by the Mabo case must now be resolved by the Torres Strait Treaty which was designed to protect indigenous rights to fishing and environmental concerns. The documentary presents all sides to the argument including interviews with the commercial fishermen, Mer Island fishermen and community leaders, and legal representatives for the Mer people as well as archival footage of Eddie “Koiki” Mabo discussing sea rights in 1989. Narrated by Aven S. Noah.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aven S Noah, Rosemary Hesp, Trevor Graham, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Australia and Junjidys Productions

results.title: All under heaven: life in a chinese village (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Carma Hinton, Richard Gordon, Dan Sape, Kathy Kline and Long Bow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Long Bow Trilogy”.
An intimate look at daily life in Long Bow - a village 600 kilometres south-west of Beijing. Ancient traditions persist - we see an elaborate funeral, a country fair, a local animal market and an open air opera. But changes have come to Long Bow, with the shift from collective to individual farming. A sense of dramatic change accompanies the simple rhythms of rural life. Part one of The Long Bow trilogy.

results.title: Small happiness : Life in a Chinese village
results.creator_credit: Carma Hinton, Richard Gordon and Long Bow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Long Bow Trilogy”.
Despite the tremendous advances women in China have made, serious problems continue. Long Bow women talk about love, marriage, work, birth control, birth customs and the now outlawed custom of foot binding. Moving interviews with Ling Qiao and her mother-in-law draw us into their lives.

results.title: All under heaven: life in a chinese village
results.creator_credit: Carma Hinton, Richard Gordon, Don Sape, Kathy Kline and Long Bow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Long Bow Trilogy”.
An intimate look at daily life in Long Bow, a village 600 kilometres south-west of Beijing in Northern China. Ancient traditions persist - we see an elaborate funeral, a country fair, a local animal market and an open air opera. Documents the changes that have come to Long Bow with the shift from collective to individual farming.

results.title: To taste 100 herbs: gods, ancestors and medicine (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Carma Hinton, Richard Gordon and Long Bow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Long Bow Trilogy”.
A rich portrait of a traditional Chinese doctor and his special role in the community. The doctor discusses his Catholic religion, medical ethics, rural health services, handed-down knowledge of herbal treatments and Western medical practices. The warmth, closeness and traditions of family life in China are wonderfully captured in scenes of prayer, play, chores and celebrations.

results.title: Small body of still water
results.creator_credit: Dietmar Fill, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A pond is a small body of still water. Within this environment the life support elements of sun, water and oxygen enable the process of photosynthesis to take place, upon which much of the life in and around the pond is dependent.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dietmar Fill, Don Murray and Film Australia
